stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on the main overworld area, programming new features. Key activities included brainstorming a new storybook-style intro cutscene, creating a dynamic star-unlock particle effect for doors, and implementing a new coin-gated NPC to guard a cannon. The stream ended with the discovery of a game-breaking bug in the dialogue system.

development_findings.summary: Kaze designed a new intro cutscene concept, transitioning from a 2D storybook art style to the 3D game world to create a unique and thematic opening.
development_findings.quote: And then right here, it turns into, like, a storybook... But then the storybook alpha overlay disappears slowly to reveal the island below it in 3D. And now with the island being in 3D, the camera pans over to Mario.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is planning a significant optimization by converting 4x4 matrices to 4x3, which will improve performance on the N64 hardware.
development_findings.quote: I am going to, maybe after this stream, turn all the 4x4 matrices finally into 4x3 matrices. Finally gonna bite into that problem. And that will be a pretty big optimization.

development_findings.summary: Kaze developed a custom 'tick' command to optimize actor behavior scripts, saving significant processing time compared to the original game's loop structure.
development_findings.quote: The tick comment is a custom behavior comment that replaces loops in the mar64 behavior... it's probably like two microseconds per actor. With 100 actors, that's like 200 microseconds you just throw away.

development_findings.summary: A new visual effect for unlocking doors was created where the required number of stars spawn, circle the player, and shower them in pixie dust, replacing a standard door unlock.
development_findings.quote: It's gonna spawn 20 stars with like two frames of a difference, and they're all gonna circle around you like that.

development_findings.summary: An idea exists to have the game's music evolve as the player rescues more Yoshis, but there are potential technical or scope-related roadblocks.
development_findings.quote: We even had a plan to progress the music as it goes along, but I'm not sure if that's still gonna be possible.

development_findings.summary: Kaze implemented a coin-based economy by creating an NPC, 'Corrupt Dom,' who charges the player 200 coins to access a cannon, adding a resource sink to the game.
development_findings.quote: I want this to cost coins, like it's important to me that some things just cost money.

development_findings.summary: Kaze demonstrated a new, graphically intensive level on original N64 hardware, using widescreen and anti-aliasing to show off the engine's capabilities.
After programming a new NPC, Kaze discovered that a recent refactor broke the entire dialogue system, halting progress until it's fixed off-stream.
development_findings.quote: Damn. Okay, we need to fix dialogues first. But I think the problem is done programming. It's just that I broke dialogues in the entire game.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a personal philosophy of discipline over motivation, believing that work should be done regardless of feeling motivated.
context_findings.quote: If you need motivation, you're already fucked up. Why do you need to feel motivated to work? Are you stupid? Just work. That's my view on this.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes game worlds are not literal 1-to-1 representations but simplified, abstract story spaces, which informs his world design.
context_findings.quote: You need to think about games more as, like, a story that you're being told, and you're being told the simplified version of the story. They're not gonna give you every unnecessary detail.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a future ambition to make the project fully copyright-free by commissioning artists to create original assets.
context_findings.quote: I feel like if we do that, I have to pay a lot of artists to make textures for us. And then you get to dictate to these artists what we want. Wouldn't that be awesome? You get to boss around people.

context_findings.summary: A previously uploaded video was taken down, preventing Kaze from playing a requested song on stream due to a past issue.
Kaze expresses frustration with Microsoft products, specifically PowerPoint, in the context of a university presentation Zeina has to do.
context_findings.quote: PowerPoint is such a fucking joke, dude. God, we don't hate Microsoft enough.

context_findings.summary: Kaze confirms the project will be open source after it is completed, but the specific 'RTYI' parts are currently kept private.

biobak.summary: Biobak created a storyboard that is the direct inspiration and foundation for the new 2D storybook-style intro cutscene.
biobak.quote: We used Biobak's storyboard, the Yoshi memory flashback installed in storybook 2D Arch.

biobak.summary: Biobak is active in the development process, providing assets or updates through Discord during the stream.
biobak.quote: Who pinched me? Oh, it's Biobak. Oh, you uploaded it to Discord.

badub.summary: Kaze mentions Badub as the person who can create the music needed for the newly brainstormed storybook intro sequence.
badub.quote: Oh yeah, I'm sure Badub can pull that up.

zeina.summary: Zeina is balancing university commitments (a presentation) with the project, which appears to be a source of stress. Kaze acknowledges this on stream.
zeina.quote: What are you talking about, Zayna? Why are you in such a bad mood? I have a presentation in university? Ugh.

key_stories.title: The Storybook Intro
key_stories.summary: Inspired by a video and using Biobak's storyboards, Kaze spontaneously designed a new intro sequence. He conceived a creative transition from a 2D storybook style to the 3D game world, verifying its technical feasibility live on stream.
key_stories.challenge: The team had an idea for an intro, but it wasn't inspiring. Kaze felt a more cinematic and thematically appropriate opening was needed.
key_stories.process: After seeing an unrelated video, Kaze was inspired. He leveraged an existing storyboard from Biobak and live-brainstormed a sequence that starts as a 2D storybook and seamlessly transitions into the 3D game world where the player takes control. He even did a quick memory calculation to ensure it was possible.
key_stories.outcome: A new, ambitious intro concept was designed on the spot. Kaze validated its technical feasibility regarding memory and planned to move forward with this much more dynamic and artistic opening.
key_stories.key_quote: Imagine this is a 3D scene... And then right here, it turns into, like, a storybook... but then the storybook alpha overlay disappears slowly to reveal the island below it in 3D.

key_stories.title: The Pixie Dust Star Shower
key_stories.summary: Kaze needed a special effect for unlocking star doors. Through live iteration, he developed a multi-stage effect where stars circle Mario and shower him in pixie dust, creating a highly satisfying visual he decided to adopt for all star-related events.
key_stories.challenge: The game requires unlocking areas with stars, but it lacks a unique visual for this action. A generic effect would be underwhelming.
key_stories.process: Kaze began programming the logic for a door that required a certain number of stars. He first made stars appear, then decided to make them circle Mario. He iterated on this, adding scaling, timing adjustments, and finally a pixie dust particle effect that falls onto Mario. He also added a dust cloud effect for when the door itself opens.
key_stories.outcome: A dynamic and visually rewarding unlock sequence was created. Kaze was so pleased with the 'pixie dust shower' effect that he decided it should be used for all star collections in the game, creating a signature visual.
key_stories.key_quote: Oh, it's showering Mario in pixie dust. Oh, that's so cool all stars should do this instead, right? That looks so much better than a normal star animation.

key_stories.title: The Corrupt Cannon Guard
key_stories.summary: To implement a coin-based progression gate, Kaze created a new NPC, 'Corrupt Dom,' from scratch. He designed its behavior, wrote dialogue, and programmed its interaction logic, only to discover at the end that a deeper, unrelated bug with the dialogue system was preventing it from working.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze wanted to gate access to a cannon behind a coin paywall to create a money sink, requiring a new NPC with specific logic.
key_stories.process: Kaze first adjusted the level geometry to create a spot for the NPC. He brainstormed character concepts, settling on a 'corrupt' black Bob-omb. He then programmed its patrol path, rotation towards Mario, and the logic for its different dialogue options (not enough money, paying, already paid).
key_stories.outcome: The 'Corrupt Dom' NPC was fully programmed with patrolling behavior and multiple dialogue states. However, the story concluded with the discovery that the entire game's dialogue system was broken from a previous refactor, a problem to be solved later.
key_stories.key_quote: I think a black Bob-omb guarding the cannon would make sense, considering he charges you money... I'm gonna call him Corrupt Dom.
